themes.title: Green as a Symbol of Prestige and Cultural Exchange
points: Green-glazed ceramics were highly valued across Asia and Europe, symbolizing prestige and luxury.
The Goryeo dynasty in Korea developed incised celadon techniques, creating wares with 'clarity of water' and 'radiance of jade.'
Chinese celadon and qingbai wares were exported widely, influencing local traditions in Korea, Japan, and Southeast Asia.
In the Qing dynasty, green enamel innovations elevated polychrome porcelain, prized by both Chinese and European courts.

themes.title: Techniques and Materials: The Art of Green Ceramics
points: Korean incised celadon (eumgak cheongja) involved carving intricate designs like parrots with knives before glazing.
Qingbai wares achieved their icy blue-green hue through iron-infused glazes fired in oxygen-deprived kilns.
Sawankhalok celadon from Thailand featured crackled olive-green glazes and unglazed bases, often used in rituals.
Famille verte porcelain from China used overglaze enamels to create vibrant green designs, leaving some areas unglazed for contrast.

themes.title: Cultural Connections and Historical Context
points: Celadon wares were central to the Japanese tea ceremony during the Kamakura period, reflecting a fascination with 'Chinese things.'
Vietnam and Thailand adapted Chinese kiln technologies to produce green-glazed ceramics for local use and export.
European collectors in the 19th century, like George Salting and Ernest Grandidier, amassed significant collections of famille verte porcelain.
Celadon's association with jade and its supposed ability to detect poison added layers of cultural significance in the Islamic world.

themes.title: Hands-On Engagement: Observing and Interpreting Green Ceramics
points: Ask students to compare the green hues in different ceramics—what emotions or ideas do they evoke?
Point out the spur marks on the Korean celadon bowl's base—discuss how potters avoided kiln residue.
Encourage students to identify symbols on the Qing dynasty famille verte bowl, like horses and waves, and discuss their meanings.
Highlight the crackled glaze on Sawankhalok miniatures—ask students to imagine how they were used in rituals.
